description: From Middle English paramour, paramoure, peramour, paramur, from Old French par amor (“for love's sake”). The modern pronunciation is apparently an Early Modern English readaptation of the French.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, of loving, etc.) Passionately, out of sexual desire.
(somewhat archaic) An illicit lover, either male or female.
examples: Synonyms: leman, mistress; see also Thesaurus:mistress
to run away with a paramour

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The Virgin Mary or Jesus Christ (when addressed by a person of the opposite sex).

verbs.description: paramour (third-person singular simple present paramours, present participle paramouring, simple past and past participle paramoured)

entries.meaning: To go with a paramour; to have an affair.
